data.body:
Other materials tested:

- [MeshBasicMaterial](https://threejs.org/docs/scenes/material-browser.html#MeshBasicMaterial) works
- [MeshDepthMaterial](https://threejs.org/docs/scenes/material-browser.html#MeshDepthMaterial) works
![screenshot from 2018-05-24 14 41 53](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/40515206-cb4a00fe-5f60-11e8-8f72-8911755e43bc.png)
- [MeshLambertMaterial](https://threejs.org/docs/#api/materials/MeshLambertMaterial) works: 
![screenshot from 2018-05-24 14 48 59](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/40515521-0425874e-5f62-11e8-9b86-5abf82e47933.png)
- [MeshPhongMaterial](https://threejs.org/docs/scenes/material-browser.html#MeshPhongMaterial) does not work:
![screenshot from 2018-05-24 14 39 38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/40515092-56d00a98-5f60-11e8-8c26-ca981ba607b7.png)

Let me know if there are any other in particular i should try out
possibly related: #12679, #12592

@WestLangley ah, thanks, good catch. Not sure how I missed those. The first one sounds likely to be the same issue. The second one sounds similar, but slightly different (Happens on Android 5.1.1 on Atom devices, whereas this _seems_ to just be v7+ and MeshLambertMaterial doesn't work for that reporter, whereas it does for me)

@mrdoob I see [you were looking for a device that exhibits this failure]( https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/12679#issuecomment-380984624). I have several here in SF. Looks like you're here too, so happy to drop one off for you (or anyone else equipped to work on this) to test on. Pinged you in three.js slack if you'd like to coordinate that

It seems most of the devices on which this has been reported use the Qualcomm Snapdragon 425*. So the issue may have something to do with that chip's Adreno 308 GPU. The one strange datapoint is that the issue was [reported to _not_  appear on one particular Samsung Galaxy J3 (SM-J327T) also running Android 7.0](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48156560/all-shapes-entities-showing-up-as-black-in-a-frame-scenes#comment83332908_48156560)

*: FWIW this chip seems to be using in most common low-/mid-range Android devices available in the market these days
Possibly texture unit limit. Alternatively, number of uniforms limit. Could you perhaps check these numbers on your devices?

@Usnul Here's the relevant info from webglreport.com. Looks like 16 (vertex)/16 (fragment) shaders, and 256 (vertex)/224 (fragment) uniforms. I only posted shots from the Aristo, but the result looks basically identical on the Fiesta (unsurprising, given it's using the same Adreno 308 GPU). Lemme know if there's anything else that would be helpful in tracking this down

![screenshot_2018-05-29-11-00-52](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/40676579-fb903bfc-632f-11e8-9dbf-1ac4a8f8f3de.png)
![screenshot_2018-05-29-11-00-56](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/40676491-bc28704c-632f-11e8-914d-5a65e7222a39.png)
![screenshot_2018-05-29-11-01-11](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/40676492-bc5033b6-632f-11e8-8892-1b56dd79fe03.png)

@gabrielgrant 
No, all looks fine to me. Like you said. So, not the uniform/texture limit :)
@Usnul definitely worth checking -- it was a good theory! :)
I'm still at a bit of a loss as to how to continue debugging this. Any more guidance as to what I could be looking into to get this fixed?

Can you please make a test with an older release of `three.js`? 

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/releases/tag/r73

R74 refactored the GLSL code for lights. Maybe this change is the cause for your rendering problems.
@Mugen87 ah, that makes sense, thanks for the context. is there any chance the official demos using the r73 are still available somewhere?

Ok, just checked it out locally. There doesn't seem to be a `MeshStandardMaterial` in this version*, but the `MeshPhongMaterial` (which was also broken in the latest release) does indeed seem to work in r73:

![screenshot from 2018-06-08 07 56 48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41165075-8af88e3e-6af1-11e8-8490-1acef771d0ee.png)

and is broken as described in this issue in r74:

![screenshot from 2018-06-08 08 03 46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41165461-992e0442-6af2-11e8-967d-d530bb48f7d3.png)


* Edit: Indeed, appears `MeshStandardMaterial` was added in [r74](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/releases/tag/r74): https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/7381

I think we can definitely say that the mentioned refactoring broke the lighting shader code for certain platforms. I suspect it's because of the usage of arrays with structured uniforms (see https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/12592#issuecomment-343283432 and 74d3aa3f12120c906d190e621cb1260e88932757).

I'm not sure how we should proceed since the problem is clearly hardware/driver related. Does the following conformance test work on your device?

https://www.khronos.org/registry/webgl/sdk/tests/conformance/glsl/misc/shader-with-array-of-structs-uniform.html?webglVersion=%5Bobject%20Object%5D

Yup, seems to pass:

![screenshot from 2018-06-08 08 28 54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41166806-09c6a0ee-6af6-11e8-931d-c848bb7f6630.png)

Um, okay. I've created an other reduced test case. Can you see both red and blue planes on your devices?

~~https://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6715/~~

A little cramped to see on mobile,but yes,it appears to work on this device: 
![screenshot_2018-06-08-08-46-08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41167731-a42d2d5e-6af8-11e8-96c5-24c04c2c20e8.png)

We need to isolate the part of the shader which is executed differently on your device. Then we have a real chance that browser implementers can validate the issue. If array with structured uniforms are not the actual problem, it must be something different...
Makes sense. Certainly happy to run whatever tests you can suggest to isolate the problem
Not sure if it will help, but currently running the full suite of conformance tests on another device with the same snapdragon processor/gpu that is exhibiting this same problem

Do you see the white box in this example. It just has a single point light (the material viewer in the documentation has three).

~~https://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6718/show~~

The full, multi-pane fiddle is again pretty hard to make out on mobile, but it seems to be just black. here's [the fiddle result as a standalone page](http://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6718/embedded/result/):
![screenshot_2018-06-08-09-29-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41169706-a4141ade-6afe-11e8-8867-2ec1e8b7564f.png)

Okay, let's see if a different precision qualifier makes a difference. We are now using `lowp` for the phong material. Any improvements?

~~http://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6720/embedded/result~~

Yup, that seems to work: 
![screenshot_2018-06-08-09-35-29](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41169932-541714b8-6aff-11e8-9092-a707a85b0f81.png)

Really?!? What about `mediump`?

~~http://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6721/embedded/result~~

Weird, that does too... I thought `mediump` was the default...?

![screenshot_2018-06-08-09-38-54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41170122-e827e29a-6aff-11e8-99a7-24aac68c0fb7.png)

No, it's `highp` if the platform supports it. Okay, one last test. We now set explicit `highp`. This should not work, right?

~~http://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6722/embedded/result~~

Confirmed: 
![screenshot_2018-06-08-09-41-39](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41170219-32b35114-6b00-11e8-9793-e757bca374cf.png)

Many thanks for your feedback! We definitely made some progress in this issue. Can you please post your device name, GPU, OS and browser you have tested with right know? This could be useful for further investigation. 

The problem is we still don't know at which place in the shader the bug happen. But it seems to be related to the usage of high precision.

To summarize:

http://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6721/embedded/result (`MeshPhongMaterial` with `mediump` does render)
http://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/6722/embedded/result (`MeshPhongMaterial` with `highp`, does not render on specific devices)

Thanks for following up on this! I'm Currently testing on LG Aristo (LG-M210) and
LG Fiesta (LG L63BL),  both of which have a Qualcomm Snapdragon 425 (which contains an Adreno 308 GPU) with chrome 66 on android 7.0 

More details here: 
https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/14137#issuecomment-392877172

![screenshot_2018-06-08-10-03-29](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/493968/41170907-42dbb5ec-6b03-11e8-89f1-0bc82408b031.png)
